description: RDMA read latency benchmark for InfiniBand and RoCE networks. Measures round-trip latency for RDMA read operations between two nodes, commonly used to verify low-latency fabric performance in HPC clusters.

installation.notes: Install via: apt install perftest or yum install perftest. Part of the standard RDMA performance testing suite.

global_options.description: Use specified port of IB device
Run all message sizes from 2 to 2^23

common_usage_patterns.description: Run as client connecting to server
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
#bytes #iterations    t_min[usec]    t_max[usec]  t_typical[usec]    t_avg[usec]    t_stdev[usec]   99% percentile[usec]   99.9% percentile[usec]
    2     1000           1.15           3.82           1.18            1.21         0.14               1.35                    2.15

common_usage_patterns.description: Test specific message size with more iterations
Use specific IB device and port

error_messages.message: Unable to find any IB devices
error_messages.resolution: Verify IB drivers are loaded and device is present with ibstat
Verify server is running, IP is correct, and port is not blocked

error_messages.meaning: Cannot create Queue Pair for RDMA
error_messages.resolution: Check IB port is active and has valid LID/GID

interoperability.notes: Part of perftest suite. Requires server mode running on remote node before client can connect. Results affected by CPU frequency scaling, NUMA placement, and network congestion.

permissions.read_operations: No special permissions for basic operation
permissions.notes: May require CAP_NET_RAW for some features or when using low-level QP types

limitations: Synthetic benchmark may not reflect application performance
Results sensitive to system tuning (CPU governor, NUMA)
Single connection test does not show fabric-wide behavior
Requires coordinated execution on both endpoints

reads_from.description: Reads IB port state for benchmark execution

triggered_by.effect: Benchmark fails if link goes down during test

consistent_with.shared_state: Latency results should be similar for same message sizes
Link rate affects achievable bandwidth (not latency for small messages)
